text: When a service is not working, use 'sudo systemctl status <service>' to check if it is active, failed, or waiting. This is usually the first step in debugging a systemd service.
If a systemd service is failing, use 'journalctl -u <service> -n 100 --no-pager' to see the latest 100 log lines. This often reveals misconfigurations, missing files, or permission errors.
Use 'df -h' to quickly see if any filesystem is full. A full root filesystem is a common reason for services failing to start or logs not being written.
Use 'du -sh /path/* | sort -h' to find which folders are taking the most disk space. This is useful when a filesystem is nearly full.
Use 'sudo dmesg -T | tail -n 50' to look for recent kernel messages. Disk I/O errors, hardware issues, or OOM kills often show up here.
Use 'sudo ss -tulpn' to list listening TCP and UDP sockets and see which process is bound to a port. This is helpful when a service cannot bind because the port is already in use.
To debug DNS or connectivity, first 'ping 1.1.1.1' or 'ping 8.8.8.8' to check raw connectivity, then 'ping google.com' to check DNS resolution.
Use 'resolvectl status' or inspect '/etc/resolv.conf' to see which DNS servers are configured on a systemd-resolved based system.
For Docker issues, 'docker ps' shows running containers, and 'docker logs <container>' shows that container's logs.
If a Docker container restarts repeatedly, use 'docker logs --tail 100 <container>' to see the last log lines and identify why it is crashing.
Use 'htop' or 'top' to check CPU and memory usage when the system feels slow. Look for processes pegging a CPU core or consuming large amounts of RAM.
If SSH is not responding, check whether the server is reachable with 'ping', and then verify 'sudo systemctl status ssh' on the host.
When editing important configuration files, it is good practice to create a backup first, e.g. 'cp file.conf file.conf.bak' before changing it.
Permission problems often manifest as 'Permission denied' or 'EACCES' errors. Use 'ls -l' to inspect permissions and 'sudo chown user:group file' or 'chmod 644 file' to fix them carefully.
